cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerA: A solid red light.
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If an officer is directing traffic at a working traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions indicated by the traffic light.
questions.answerB: Follow the directions given by the officer.
questions.answerC: Honk at the officer.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: Traffic signals are placed at intersections to keep traffic moving and to help prevent crashes. Drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists must obey these signals, except in instances when an officer is directing traffic.

questions.question: The fee for an instruction permit is:
questions.explanation: The minimum age to acquire an instruction permit is 15 years old. This permit allows a young person to learn to drive with the supervision of a licensed adult. The fee to obtain this permit is $3.50. Application test fees are not included.

questions.question: To check your blind spot when changing lanes to the left, you should glance:
questions.answerA: Over your right shoulder.
questions.answerB: At your side mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your left shoulder.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot, glance over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Winding road.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield just to the traffic on the right.
questions.answerC: Yield just to the traffic on the left.
questions.answerD: Slow down and yield the right-of-way to other traffic.
questions.explanation: A yield sign means that you must slow down and yield the right-of-way to traffic in the intersection or roadway you are entering.

questions.question: When you are being tailgated:
questions.answerA: Move over to the right, if there is an open lane to your right.
questions.answerB: If there is not an open lane to your right, wait until the way is clear ahead and reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerC: Never slow down abruptly.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated by another driver and there is a right lane, move over to the right. If there is no right lane, wait until the road ahead is clear and then reduce your speed slowly. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you. Never slow down abruptly as this will only increase the risk of your vehicle being hit from behind.

questions.question: You must pull over to the edge of the road and allow an emergency vehicle to pass:
questions.answerA: Regardless of your direction.
questions.answerB: Only if it is following you.
questions.answerC: Only if it is approaching you from the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: You must pull over to the right edge of the road and stop for an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, regardless of whether it is approaching you from behind or from the opposite direction.

questions.question: To change lanes you should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and signal, then change lanes.
questions.answerB: Signal, check your mirrors, check your blind spot in the direction you plan to move, then change lanes.
questions.answerC: Signal, check your mirrors, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should activate your turn signal in the appropriate direction and check your rearview and side mirrors. Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move in order to check your blind spot and check the far lane to be sure no one else is trying to enter the same lane as you. Change lanes when you are sure it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Motorcycles are entitled to:
questions.answerA: The bicycle lane.
questions.answerB: The same full lane width as other motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Half the width of a lane.
questions.explanation: Lane usage for the motorcyclist is critical. Motorcycles are entitled to the same full lane width as all other vehicles.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down. If possible, change lanes so you will not drive next to the stopped emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and continue to drive at the same speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to quickly pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space. If there is only one lane moving in your direction, or if changing lanes would be unsafe, you must slow down to a speed below the posted speed limit and give the stationary vehicle as much room as possible. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Narrow bridge ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass a slow-moving truck.
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Let it go.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: When changing lanes on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal a lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview and outside mirrors.
questions.answerC: Check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Any time you want to change lanes, you should properly signal your intentions well in advance, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot. You can check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: If you leave your vehicle unattended, you must:
questions.answerA: Turn off the engine.
questions.answerB: Lock the ignition and remove the key.
questions.answerC: Set the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When you leave your vehicle unattended, you must stop the engine, lock the ignition, remove the key from the ignition, and set the parking brake.

questions.question: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or using a guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Take the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Proceed normally.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: To let others know that you want to be an organ donor, you should:
questions.answerA: Complete the organ donor information on the back of your license.
questions.answerB: Discuss your decision with your next of kin.
questions.answerC: Have two witnesses sign the back of your license.
questions.explanation: To ensure your decision to be an organ donor, either enroll online or in person when applying for or renewing your permit or license. Completely fill out the back of your permit or license and inform your family.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is a very safe driver.
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible.
questions.answerB: Not move your vehicle under any circumstances.
questions.answerC: Wait until the police arrive before moving your vehicle.
questions.explanation: After a minor collision, move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible. Do not leave the scene of an accident without identifying yourself and rendering assistance.

questions.question: Your first response to reduced visibility should be:
questions.answerA: Turning on your headlights.
questions.answerB: Reducing your speed.
questions.answerC: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Looking for road edge markings to guide you.
questions.explanation: Reducing your speed should be your first response to decreased visibility and dangerous road conditions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel at the speed indicated.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal speed on the roadway is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed.
questions.explanation: This is a speed limit sign. It indicates the maximum legal speed that you may drive on the road where it is posted. At times of rain, snow, ice, or other less-than-ideal conditions, you may have to drive more slowly than the posted limit.

questions.question: The most common color of warning signs is:
questions.answerA: Red.
questions.answerB: Yellow.
questions.answerC: Green.
questions.explanation: Most warning signs are diamond-shaped and yellow with black markings. These signs warn drivers about unexpected conditions that may not be readily apparent.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: SATOP is an abbreviation for:
questions.answerA: Substance Abuse Traffic Offender Program.
questions.answerB: Salt And Tar On Pavement.
questions.answerC: Steer At The Other Point.
questions.explanation: SATOP is an abbreviation for Substance Abuse Traffic Offender Program. Completing this program is a requirement of those convicted of alcohol-related driving offenses.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Pass only on the right.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: School crossing.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. You should watch for people entering a crosswalk or crossing your path. Slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: If you operate a motor vehicle while intoxicated and you injure or kill another person, you:
questions.answerA: Will only have to pay a fine.
questions.answerB: Will only spend time in jail.
questions.answerC: Will only lose your license.
questions.answerD: May lose your license and be sentenced to jail.
questions.explanation: Operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated is both illegal and dangerous. If you are driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol and you cause an accident that injures or kills another person, you may be sentenced to two to seven years in jail, be required to pay a $5,000 fine, and lose your license for five years.

questions.question: The most important thing to remember about speed management and curves is that you must:
questions.answerA: Drive at the posted speed limit as you enter the curve, then slow down at the sharpest part of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down before you enter the curve.
questions.answerC: Accelerate gently before you enter the curve.
questions.answerD: Drive at the posted speed limit before, throughout, and after the curve.
questions.explanation: The most important thing to remember about driving in curves is that your vehicle’s inertia may make it difficult to turn. To maintain control, it is essential that you slow down before entering the curve.

questions.question: The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to:
questions.answerA: Keep your tires properly maintained.
questions.answerB: Slow down when roads are wet or slushy.
questions.answerC: Watch out for standing water or puddles.
questions.explanation: When roads are wet, cars take a longer distance to stop and may skid on quick turns. Do not use cruise control when driving under wet or icy conditions. Reduce your speed and drive with caution.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: What is the appropriate action to take when approaching a railroad crossing that does not have signals to direct traffic?
questions.answerA: Always bring the car to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerC: All railroad crossings have signals so you will never encounter this situation.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get across the tracks quickly.
questions.explanation: When approaching an unmarked railroad crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Before you cross, be sure that no trains are approaching from either direction on any track. If you see or hear a train coming, stop at a safe distance from the nearest track and wait to proceed until after the train passes.

questions.question: An inattentive driver is a driver who:
questions.answerA: Stares at objects off the roadway or daydreams while driving.
questions.answerB: Maintains eye contact during a conversation with a passenger while driving.
questions.answerC: Only watches the vehicle ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. Continue scanning the road, checking your mirrors, and looking at the instrument panel at regular intervals. Developing these safe habits will keep you attentive as a driver.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerA: The effect that alcohol has.
questions.answerB: The effect that amphetamines have.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn ahead, slow down.
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: Points:
questions.answerA: Are nothing to worry about.
questions.answerB: Are a good thing to have on your driving record.
questions.answerC: Are helpful if you want to get a job driving.
questions.answerD: Are something you don’t want on your driving record.
questions.explanation: When you are convicted of a traffic violation while your vehicle is in motion, the department receives notice and adds points to your driving record. You can lose your driving privilege when you accumulate too many points.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: What should you do when you are going to enter a roadway from a private road?
questions.answerA: Blow your horn to warn cars you are entering the roadway.
questions.answerB: Stop with part of your car on the roadway to alert other drivers.
questions.answerC: Drive out fast to merge smoothly with the traffic.
questions.answerD: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a roadway from a driveway or private road, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and traffic on the roadway.

questions.question: When driving in rain, you must:
questions.answerA: Use low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Use high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use parking lights.
questions.explanation: In rainy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: A “No stopping” sign means that, unless directed to do so by a police officer, you may stop only:
questions.answerA: Long enough to unload packages.
questions.answerB: To avoid conflict with other traffic.
questions.answerC: To discharge passengers.
questions.explanation: A "No stopping" sign means you can only stop to obey a traffic signal, to obey a police officer, or to prevent a conflict with another vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If you drive past these signs, you are going the wrong way and are at risk of a head-on collision. You should cautiously turn around.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerA: A steady red light
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Your current roadway ends ahead.
questions.answerB: You must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a Y intersection ahead. You must bear either to the right or to the left.

questions.question: What does a flashing yellow traffic light mean?
questions.answerA: Merging traffic
questions.answerB: Proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light indicates that you should drive with caution.

questions.question: Many crashes are caused by:
questions.answerA: Drivers traveling too fast for conditions.
questions.answerB: Drivers consistently checking their mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerC: Drivers yielding the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Drivers maintaining a four-second following distance.
questions.explanation: Many crashes are caused by drivers who are driving too fast for conditions. Always drive within the legal speed limits and decrease your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: What are the colors of warning signs indicating upcoming hazards?
questions.answerA: Black letters or symbols on a white background
questions.answerB: Black letters or symbols on a yellow background
questions.answerC: White letters or symbols on a blue background
questions.answerD: White letters or symbols on a green background
questions.explanation: Warning signs that indicate approaching hazards are usually yellow with black lettering or symbols. Warning signs in work zones are orange with black lettering or symbols.

questions.question: A license plate frame:
questions.answerA: May cover the word "Missouri" on the plate.
questions.answerB: Should not cover any information on the plate.
questions.answerC: May cover the month and year registration stickers.
questions.answerD: May cover the wording at the bottom of the plate.
questions.explanation: Missouri law requires that license plates be securely fastened to a vehicle and that all parts of the plates are visible and clean for view or inspection by any law enforcement entity. If you have frames around your license plates, the Missouri State Highway Patrol requires that the frames do not cover any part of the plates.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: A driver can legally pass on the right side of another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle is waiting to turn left and there is an available passing lane.
questions.answerB: Even if it means driving off the pavement.
questions.answerC: On a narrow bridge.
questions.explanation: If there is an available passing lane, you may pass on the right of a vehicle or bicycle that is turning left or waiting to turn left. It is also legal to pass on the right when driving on a multilane road with two or more lanes traveling in the same direction. You may never drive off the pavement or main-traveled portion of the road to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: Drivers may not pass from either side of a ____ centerline.
questions.answerA: Combination solid and broken yellow
questions.answerB: Single broken yellow
questions.answerC: Double solid yellow
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a two-way road means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the center to pass.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A green arrow:
questions.answerA: Is used only on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic must turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Means that you may proceed, but only if the green arrow is accompanied by a circular green light.
questions.answerD: Points the way to an airport.
questions.explanation: A green arrow has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic in the indicated lane must turn in the direction shown by the arrow.

questions.question: As you drive, you're required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At an intersection with a stop sign.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red light.
questions.answerC: When a traffic officer orders you to stop.
questions.explanation: Situations where motorists are required to stop include approaching intersections with stop signs, approaching intersections where a red light is either flashing or illuminated, or any time when a traffic officer orders your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: A flashing red light on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal is broken.
questions.answerC: You do not have to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means the same thing as a stop sign. If you encounter a flashing red light, you should come to a complete stop, yield to appropriate traffic and pedestrians, and only proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Have to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Are passing another car.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: When parking your vehicle downhill on a two-way street:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels pointed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: When you park on a downward-facing slope, turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll downhill, it will roll away from traffic.

questions.question: If two vehicles arrive to a four-way stop at the same time:
questions.answerA: The vehicle on the left must yield to the vehicle on the right.
questions.answerB: The vehicle on the right must yield to the vehicle on the left.
questions.answerC: Drivers must make hand motions to communicate with each other.
questions.answerD: One driver should proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles at a four-way stop should proceed in the order that they arrive. However, if two vehicles arrive to the intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the left must yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Low clearance.
questions.answerB: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching an area with low clearance.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The left lane is reserved for vehicles with a specific number of occupants.
questions.answerB: Specific turning movements are allowed from specific lanes.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.answerD: Drivers in both lanes are responsible for merging smoothly.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a high occupancy vehicle (HOV) lane. HOV lanes are reserved for use by buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers, as indicated on the sign.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for trucks.
questions.answerB: Do not pass trucks.
questions.answerC: Truck parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a hill ahead.

questions.question: The posted speed limit shows:
questions.answerA: Only a recommended driving speed.
questions.answerB: The exact speed at which you must travel to avoid a ticket.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe driving speed under ideal road and weather conditions.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe driving speed under all road conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit sign shows the maximum legal driving speed for the stretch of highway where it is posted. Driving safely may require you to travel more slowly than the posted limit. When conditions are less than ideal, drivers should slow down.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Unbuckle your seat belt and lower your window.
questions.answerB: Get your paperwork ready before the officer reaches your car.
questions.answerC: Stay in your vehicle with your hands on the steering wheel and wait for the officer to approach you.
questions.answerD: Get out of your car and walk toward the patrol car.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by the police, keep your hands on the wheel and ask any passengers to keep their hands in view as well. You should remain in the vehicle unless the police officer asks you to get out. Wait until the officer asks you to retrieve your driver license, registration, and insurance cards.

questions.question: A single broken yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Left turn yield on green.
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Your body gets rid of approximately:
questions.answerA: Three alcoholic drinks an hour.
questions.answerB: One alcoholic drink an hour.
questions.answerC: Two alcoholic drinks an hour.
questions.explanation: The average person’s body will process about one alcoholic drink in one hour. However, many factors play a part in determining how impaired a person will become when consuming alcohol, including the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast it is consumed, and a person’s body weight, food intake, and general health.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get some coffee.
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: You may drink alcoholic beverages in a vehicle on a public highway:
questions.answerA: As long as you aren't driving.
questions.answerB: If you are riding in the back seat.
questions.answerC: If you are riding in the back of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to consume or possess any alcoholic beverage while on a public road or sidewalk. Additionally, storing an open alcoholic beverage container in an area of a motor vehicle normally occupied by the driver or passenger is prohibited on any public road.

questions.question: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get out of the car and go for help.
questions.answerB: Lay down in your car and go to sleep.
questions.answerC: Walk into the road and get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerD: Stay in the car, as you are most likely to be found when you stay in your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is stay in your car and wait for help. You are most likely to be found if you don't leave your vehicle. Additionally, it may be unsafe to walk around outside in a snowstorm.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on an interstate expressway:
questions.answerA: Stop and make a U-turn.
questions.answerB: Get off at the next exit and come back to the exit you missed.
questions.answerC: Roll down your window and ask the driver next to you for help.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up or try to turn around on the highway. Go to the next exit and safely turn around.

questions.question: For a driver with an intermediate license, driving restrictions include:
questions.answerA: That a seat belt must be worn by the driver.
questions.answerB: That seat belts must be worn by all passengers.
questions.answerC: A curfew between 1:00 a.m and 5:00 a.m.
questions.explanation: Young drivers with an intermediate license may not drive alone between 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., except to and from a school activity or job, or in an emergency. Seat belts must be worn by the driver and all passengers.

questions.question: When driving past a vehicle that has just stopped in a parked position on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume that the driver will open the car door as you approach.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver will wait for you to pass before opening the door.
questions.explanation: When passing a vehicle that has just parked parallel to the road, you should assume the driver will open the door as you approach. Use extra caution when driving near parked vehicles.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: Signaling your intentions before turning, changing lanes, or driving away from a curb:
questions.answerA: Is necessary only if other traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Is a good driving habit and is required by law.
questions.answerC: Is necessary only during the maneuver, not before.
questions.answerD: Is not necessary if the maneuver is done slowly.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes or turning, signal your intentions well in advance. The law requires that you signal for at least 100 feet before you move your vehicle to the right or left. Before pulling away from a curb, always signal to inform passing drivers of your intentions.

questions.question: When a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System starts to lose traction on a slippery road, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Press and hold the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: If their vehicle loses traction on a slippery road, a driver with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) needs to press down hard on the brake pedal, hold it, and steer out of danger. In an emergency situation, the ABS automatically pumps the brakes at a faster rate than the driver could. Removing steady pressure from the brake pedal or pumping the brakes will disengage the ABS.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: You are driving on a highway divided by two solid yellow lines. You may:
questions.answerA: Cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.
questions.answerB: Cross these lines to pass other vehicles, but only if there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Cross these lines under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: Cross these lines only to make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are used to mark roadways where passing is prohibited from both directions. You may cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.

questions.question: If you need to stop quickly and your vehicle is not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Hold down the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Firmly pump your brakes.
questions.answerC: Lightly tap the brakes.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brakes is generally the best way to stop a car in an emergency. The car will stop quickly and you will also be able to continue steering.

questions.question: Roads freeze quickly when they are:
questions.answerA: Flat.
questions.answerB: Curvy.
questions.answerC: In the sun.
questions.explanation: In cold or wet weather, you should take special care on sections of road that are shaded by trees or buildings. These areas freeze more quickly than the rest of the road and are the last parts of the road to dry.

questions.question: Work zone signs mean:
questions.answerA: It is summer.
questions.answerB: You must immediately stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Less than ideal conditions are present for driving.
questions.answerD: You should drive faster to get out of the work zone.
questions.explanation: Work zone signs are orange and indicate that some type of work is being performed on or alongside the roadway. Be extremely careful when you see these signs.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerA: Either side
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerA: Allergy medicine
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Other drivers who are already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians who are already in the intersection.
questions.explanation: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. Drivers must also always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers who are already in the intersection.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerA: Increases your field of vision.
questions.answerB: Decreases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: To turn left from multilane, one-way streets and highways, you should start from:
questions.answerA: The middle of the intersection.
questions.answerB: The right lane.
questions.answerC: The left lane.
questions.explanation: To turn left from multilane streets and highways, start from the left lane.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow arrow indicates that left turns are allowed in the direction of the arrow. However, the oncoming traffic has a green light and you must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: It is important to slow down:
questions.answerA: On narrow or winding roads.
questions.answerB: At intersections or railroad crossings.
questions.answerC: When the road is wet or slippery.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down when driving on narrow or winding roads, near intersections, near railroad crossings, on hills, in sharp or blind curves, where there are pedestrians or driving hazards, and when the roads are wet or slippery.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerA: Do not affect driving abilities.
questions.answerB: Help maintain driver alertness.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Keep to the side indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: You may drive in the left lane.
questions.explanation: This is a "Keep right" sign. It indicates that a traffic island, median, or barrier is ahead and that drivers must keep to the right of it.

questions.question: Allow a larger space cushion than usual when stopping:
questions.answerA: On an incline.
questions.answerB: At an intersection.
questions.answerC: At a stop sign.
questions.explanation: You should allow more space in front of your vehicle than usual when you are stopped on an uphill slope. If the vehicle in front of you rolls backward toward your vehicle when traffic begins to move again, it is less likely that there will be a collision.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are usually ____ and should always be obeyed.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs regulate the movement of traffic. They are usually white with black markings and must always be obeyed by motorists.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerA: Only in an emergency.
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you are ordered to install an ignition interlock device in your vehicle, the costs of installation and the monthly inspection must be paid by:
questions.answerA: The court clerk.
questions.answerB: The police officer.
questions.answerC: You.
questions.explanation: An ignition interlock device (IID) is a mechanical unit that is connected to the vehicle’s ignition, horn, and headlights and measures the concentration of alcohol in a person’s breath. If you have more than one alcohol-related contact showing on your driver record, you must have an IID installed on any vehicle you operate before your driving privileges can be reinstated. You must pay for having the device installed and for having it serviced every month.

questions.question: The minimum and maximum speed limits on Missouri interstate highways are:
questions.answerA: 40 mph and 55 mph.
questions.answerB: 40 mph and 70 mph.
questions.answerC: 30 mph and 70 mph.
questions.explanation: You may never drive at speeds faster than 70 mph on Missouri's interstate highways. You may not drive more slowly than 40 mph on interstate highways, under normal roadway conditions.

questions.question: When parking uphill on a hill or incline with a curb:
questions.answerA: Turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn your front wheels slightly to the right.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb.
questions.explanation: To keep your vehicle from rolling into traffic when parked facing uphill, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. If you are parking uphill on a street that has no curb, turn the wheels sharply toward the edge of the road.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This sign tells drivers the direction in which they must drive when turning onto a one-way street.

questions.question: A “No right on red” sign means:
questions.answerA: Even if the traffic signal is red, you may turn right.
questions.answerB: If the traffic signal is red, you cannot turn right.
questions.answerC: The intersection has a high number of traffic crashes.
questions.answerD: Even if the traffic signal is red, you do not have to come to a stop.
questions.explanation: After coming to a complete stop, you may often turn right on a red light if the way is clear of pedestrians and traffic. However, you must not turn right on a red light when a “No right on red” sign is also posted.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep downgrade.
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. They should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid brake damage or collision.

questions.question: Which of the following about winter driving is not true?
questions.answerA: Winter is the most difficult driving season.
questions.answerB: Checking your vehicle's antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels is especially important during the winter.
questions.answerC: Using cruise control in winter weather is a safe thing to do.
questions.answerD: It is best to use snow tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should not use cruise control on snow, in rain, in fog, or under similar hazardous conditions. Winter is the most difficult driving season and requires extra caution from drivers. It is important to consistently check your antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels. Using snow tires can increase a vehicle's traction on the surface of slippery roads.

questions.question: A steady yellow signal light means:
questions.answerA: The traffic signal is changing from green to red.
questions.answerB: You should slam on your brakes.
questions.answerC: You should increase your speed.
questions.answerD: The car in front of you is going too slowly.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light tells you the traffic signal is changing from green to red. Slow down and stop for a steady yellow light, unless you are already within the intersection or cannot safely stop before entering the intersection.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn.
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: When a person buys a vehicle, they must title the vehicle within:
questions.answerA: 30 days.
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.answerC: One week.
questions.explanation: When you buy a vehicle, you must apply for a title within 30 days. If you do not apply within 30 days, you will have to pay a penalty fee.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerA: Are usually not important.
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: A work zone:
questions.answerA: May be moving or stationary.
questions.answerB: Is marked with black and white signs.
questions.answerC: Does not require a driver to slow down and pay extra attention.
questions.explanation: Work zones are often stationary, but they may also be present in the form of moving vehicles striping lines, mowing, or removing snow. Work zones are marked by orange signs with black lettering or symbols. Slow down and pay extra attention when approaching or driving through a work zone.

questions.question: Traffic signs and pavement markings:
questions.answerA: Must always be obeyed.
questions.answerB: Are merely suggestions.
questions.answerC: Must be followed only when there is other traffic.
questions.answerD: Must be followed only when a police officer is present.
questions.explanation: Traffic flow is controlled by pavement markings, traffic islands, signals, and signs. These devices inform drivers of conditions on the roadway and help guide drivers safely to their destinations. You must always obey traffic signs, signals, and pavement markings.

questions.question: Driving at night requires increased caution because:
questions.answerA: Traffic moves faster at night.
questions.answerB: There is a larger volume of traffic at night.
questions.answerC: Drivers cannot see as well at night.
questions.answerD: Accidents occur more frequently at night.
questions.explanation: Because it is dark, drivers cannot see as well at night as they can during the day. From one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when persons or vehicles are not visible for 500 feet, drivers must use their headlights.

questions.question: A telltale sign of a drunk driver is:
questions.answerA: They are weaving between lanes.
questions.answerB: They are driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow.
questions.answerC: They are making quick and sudden stops.
questions.explanation: Telltale signs of drunk driving include speeding, weaving, driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow, making jerking motions, and making quick and sudden stops.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate:
questions.answerA: Stop on the shoulder of the road if you are tired.
questions.answerB: You should always use cruise control.
questions.answerC: Signal, check mirrors, and check blind spots before changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Signal, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot before changing lanes or passing on an interstate. Only stop on the shoulder of the interstate in the case of an emergency and change lanes as infrequently as possible. Cruise control should not be used in heavy traffic or under poor weather conditions.

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an approaching emergency vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Motion for the emergency vehicle to pass you.
questions.answerD: Merge into the right lane and continue driving.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to any approaching emergency vehicle that is using its flashing lights or siren, regardless of its direction of travel. You must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, pass through the intersection before coming to a stop on the right side of the road.

questions.question: When driving in fog:
questions.answerA: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerB: Use your low beams.
questions.answerC: Use your high beams.
questions.answerD: It makes no difference which lights you use.
questions.explanation: You should use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow.

questions.question: When approaching an uncontrolled intersection, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Maintain their speed and proceed.
questions.answerB: Stop at the intersection, check in all directions, and proceed.
questions.answerC: Yield to all other drivers.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where there is no stop sign or traffic signal, you should yield to a vehicle approaching the intersection from the right. However, always be prepared to yield to avoid a crash. Do this by taking your foot off the accelerator, covering the brake, and looking left, right, and left again.

questions.question: The youngest age a person may be to obtain an instruction permit is:
questions.answerA: 14 years old.
questions.answerB: 15 years old.
questions.answerC: 15 and one-half years old.
questions.explanation: Young drivers are eligible for an instruction permit at the age of 15. This permit allows a young person to learn to drive with the supervision of a licensed adult.

questions.question: Signs that are colored orange are:
questions.answerA: Work zone signs.
questions.answerB: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerC: School zone signs.
questions.explanation: Highway work zones are established according to the type of work underway along the roadway. Signs in work areas are typically diamond-shaped, orange, have black letters or symbols, and serve as a warning that people are working on or near the highway.

questions.question: A seat belt should be adjusted so that it:
questions.answerA: Is loose.
questions.answerB: Is buckled snugly across your hip bones and lower abdomen.
questions.answerC: Is hidden beneath the seat.
questions.answerD: Keeps the seat belt buzzer or light from operating.
questions.explanation: Lap belts should fit snugly across your hip bones and the lower part of your abdomen. Shoulder belts should sit comfortably so that you can insert your fist between the belt and your chest.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No parking.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: “Highway hypnosis” is a driving condition that can result from:
questions.answerA: Staring at the roadway for long periods of time.
questions.answerB: Frequent rest stops.
questions.answerC: Too much sleep the night before your trip.
questions.explanation: "Highway hypnosis” happens when you stare straight ahead at the roadway for long periods of time and stop actively scanning ahead, behind, and around your vehicle. This can lead you to zone out, making you very likely to crash into traffic slowing or stopping ahead of you.

questions.question: If your car starts to skid, turn your steering wheel:
questions.answerA: To keep the front wheels straight.
questions.answerB: In the direction you want the vehicle to go.
questions.answerC: In the opposite direction of the skid.
questions.answerD: In any direction. It doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a skid, you should turn the steering wheel in the direction you want the vehicle to go. As soon as the vehicle begins to straighten out, turn the steering wheel back the other way.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Look for a train.
questions.answerC: Be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: When you see any signs indicating a nearby railroad crossing, you should slow down, look for a train, and be ready to stop. If the red warning lights are flashing or the gate is down, you must stop 15 to 50 feet before the railroad tracks. Do not try to go around the gate.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto the shoulder of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Stop your car on the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Slow down and very carefully turn back onto the pavement.
questions.answerD: Maintain your speed and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto a low shoulder, you should reduce your speed without braking and very carefully turn back onto the pavement. Be aware of any nearby traffic when re-entering the road.

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerA: Decreases blood alcohol concentration.
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: Road rage and aggressive driving may be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Allowing extra travel time.
questions.answerB: Obeying posted speed limits.
questions.answerC: Using proper turn signals.
questions.explanation: As an increasing number of drivers populate the roadways, road rage becomes more prevalent. To help prevent road rage, a driver should use proper turn signals, obey posted speed limits, and allow plenty of travel time.

questions.question: A speed limit is:
questions.answerA: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under dangerous conditions.
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.answerC: The suggested speed to travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit is the maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed, but it is illegal to drive any faster. You must drive more slowly where signs or signs indicate a school zone or work zone speed limit. If conditions such as road construction or bad weather make the posted speed unsafe, drive under the speed limit.

questions.question: Two solid yellow lines on the pavement mean:
questions.answerA: Passing is allowed for drivers from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is not allowed.
questions.answerC: Passing is allowed if you are at the top a hill.
questions.answerD: Passing is allowed during daylight only.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines tell you that the traffic on the other side of the lines is moving in the opposite direction. You should never cross two solid yellow lines to pass from either direction.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: Your brake lights tell other drivers that you:
questions.answerA: Are making a turn.
questions.answerB: Have your emergency brake on.
questions.answerC: Are changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's brake lights indicate to other drivers that you are slowing down or stopping. Your brake lights should always be in working order when you are driving on any roadway.

questions.question: A speed restriction sign:
questions.answerA: May be ignored in rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.
questions.answerB: Has a triangular shape.
questions.answerC: Is blue with black lettering.
questions.answerD: Shows a recommended speed for a curve or turn.
questions.explanation: Curve and turn warning signs often have attached advisory speed signs that show a recommended driving speed for drivers in the curves and turns. Although a driver may feel comfortable driving at a higher speed in fair weather, they should never do so under rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: If you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must not pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: May pass a slow-moving vehicle if you can do so quickly.
questions.answerC: May pass if you know the road ahead.
questions.answerD: May pass, but only at night.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are white, rectangular signs with black markings. Drivers must obey the instructions posted on all regulatory signs. Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited for drivers to pass one another.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: Blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Your body weight.
questions.answerB: How much you drink.
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks.
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. It is not affected by the type of alcoholic beverages you drink, your level of physical fitness, or how well you can "hold your liquor."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a detour ahead.
questions.answerB: You must stop for flaggers.
questions.answerC: The road ahead is closed to traffic.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead is undergoing maintenance.
questions.explanation: Construction and maintenance signs are orange-colored and are used to notify drivers of unusual or potentially dangerous conditions in or near work areas. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a construction zone and that they should prepare to lower their speed and drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: Curve.
questions.answerC: Turn right or left.
questions.answerD: Traffic flows only in the direction of the arrow.
questions.explanation: This one-way sign indicates that traffic flows only in the direction of the arrow.

questions.question: After stopping for a school bus that is unloading children:
questions.answerA: Do not proceed until the children wave to you.
questions.answerB: Watch for children walking along the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: After stopping for a school bus that has its stop arm extended and its lights flashing, watch for children walking along the side of the road. You should always drive with caution when driving near children.

questions.question: To drive safely at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerB: Not drive if you are tired.
questions.answerC: Make sure your headlights are working properly.
questions.explanation: At night, visibility is reduced. Take steps to make driving in the dark more safe for you and the other drivers on the road.

questions.question: When driving in traffic, it is safest to:
questions.answerA: Fluctuate your speed to keep alert.
questions.answerB: Drive faster than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive with the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen when some drivers go faster or slower than other vehicles on the road. Always try to drive with the flow of traffic, within the posted speed limit.

questions.question: If an oncoming driver is heading toward you in your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn, steer right, and accelerate.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn, steer left, and brake.
questions.answerC: Blow your horn, steer right, and brake.
questions.answerD: Stay in the center of your lane, blow your horn, and brake.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle is approaching you head-on in your lane, you should first honk your horn to attract attention. If the other driver does not move over, try to escape to the right. If you swerve left and the other driver corrects at the last instant, you will still crash. If a collision is unavoidable, brake firmly and steadily. Every mile per hour you slow down will reduce the impact.

questions.question: You notice that the driver in the vehicle ahead of you is driving with one hand and talking to a passenger. You should:
questions.answerA: Give the vehicle extra space.
questions.answerB: Know that the driver in the vehicle ahead is reducing their safety margin by being an inattentive driver.
questions.answerC: Avoid following the driver's example.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. If a driver near you seems distracted, allow them extra space because the risk of an accident is increased by their inattentiveness.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: If a flagger is directing traffic in a construction zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the flagger.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the flagger's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the flagger is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow the laws that would be in place if the area was not under construction.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, flagger, or law enforcement officer. Failure to do so is illegal and is dangerous to those working in construction zones.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid yellow arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular yellow traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Tells drivers that a green arrow is about to be shown.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow has the same meaning as a yellow traffic light. When approaching a solid yellow arrow, you must reduce your speed and prepare for a red light.

questions.question: Which of the following influence(s) the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: The amount of food in the stomach
questions.answerB: The body weight of an individual
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. Eating before or while you drink helps slow the absorption of alcohol somewhat, but it cannot prevent intoxication or impairment if you have too much to drink.

questions.question: You are driving in the right lane of a multilane highway and want to move into the left lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Look in your rearview mirror for traffic behind you before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Look over your left shoulder for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Look in your side mirror for traffic and turn on your directional signal.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should always verify that there are no other vehicles in the lane you want to enter by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. You should signal every time you change lanes.

questions.question: An "End school zone" sign indicates:
questions.answerA: That the speed limit is 20 mph.
questions.answerB: The beginning of a reduced speed zone.
