questions.answerC: The increased possibility of encountering pedestrians.
questions.answerD: The end of a reduced speed zone.
questions.explanation: Do not exceed the school zone speed limit during indicated times. The end of a reduced speed school zone will be indicated by an "End school zone" regulatory sign.

questions.question: Before passing another vehicle, you should signal:
questions.answerA: Just before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: At any time.
questions.answerC: After changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Early enough for others to know your plans.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you should signal early enough for other drivers to know your plans in advance.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This signs indicate that U-turns are prohibited in the location where it is posted.

questions.question: You are driving on the roadway and hear a siren behind you. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop where you are.
questions.answerB: Pull over to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of the way.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle coming from behind your vehicle, you must create a clear path for the emergency vehicle and stop. Reduce your speed and safely pull over to the side of the road. If the emergency vehicle is directly behind your vehicle when you are in heavy traffic, keep moving slowly until you can get out of its way.

questions.question: If you fail the driving test three times:
questions.answerA: The examiner will give you a Driving Skills Examination Report.
questions.answerB: You must send your Examination Report to the Department of Revenue.
questions.answerC: The Department of Revenue will require driver training.
questions.explanation: If you fail the driving test three times, no further tests will be allowed without written authorization from the Department of Revenue. The examiner will give you a form that you must send to the department. After you send the form to the department, you will receive a letter from the department requiring additional behind-the-wheel driver training.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerA: CD player
questions.answerB: Radio
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: What does a single dashed white line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Lanes move in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic that are moving in the same direction. Dashed white lines may be crossed to pass or change lanes, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: To pass a slower-moving vehicle on a two-lane, two-way road, you must:
questions.answerA: Not cross the centerline.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Use the lane that belongs to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: Passing on a two-lane, two-way road requires good judgment because you must use the lane belonging to oncoming traffic to complete your pass. Only pass if you may safely and legally do so.

questions.question: When merging onto a freeway, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Proceed slowly while waiting for an opening.
questions.answerB: Accelerate to a speed that is faster than the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights until safely on the freeway.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a freeway, use the on-ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic so you can blend in smoothly and safely. Entering traffic must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: Double curve.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.

questions.question: You are coming to a railroad crossing where the crossing signals are flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for a train.
questions.answerB: Slow down and look for a train.
questions.answerC: Look for a train, then speed up.
questions.answerD: Do what the vehicle ahead of you does.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must stop your vehicle no closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail if an installed electric or mechanical signal is giving warning of an approaching train. Be aware of other warning signs that may indicate an oncoming train, including seeing a lowered crossing gate or hearing an oncoming train.

questions.question: When making a right or left turn, a driver should signal ____ in advance of the turn.
questions.answerA: 100 feet
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 35 feet
questions.explanation: Before you change lanes or make a turn, let other drivers know what you are going to do by signaling. You can signal with your hand and arm or with your vehicle’s turn signals and brake lights. You should signal at least 100 feet before you change lanes or turn so the other drivers can be ready to react to your movements.

questions.question: Which of the following recommendations does not promote safe night driving?
questions.answerA: Keep your windshield clean.
questions.answerB: Be aware that tinted windows reduce visibility in the dark.
questions.answerC: Carry a flashlight in your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look into the headlights of oncoming vehicles.
questions.explanation: If you look into the headlights of an oncoming vehicle, the pupil of your eye will contract. After the oncoming vehicle has passed, there will be an interval of time during which the pupil must readjust to the less intense light. During this recovery period, you are virtually driving blind.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle by using the shoulder of the road:
questions.answerA: When the vehicle in front of you is making a left turn.
questions.answerB: To go around a slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: When the traffic ahead is blocked for up to 250 feet.
questions.explanation: Never pass on the shoulder. Other drivers will not expect you to be there and may pull off the road without looking.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop their vehicle at or near the scene.
questions.answerB: Not stand or walk in traffic lanes.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignitions of wrecked vehicles.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident, you must stop at or near the scene. Move your vehicle out of the way of traffic, if possible. Do not stand or walk in traffic lanes as you could be struck by another vehicle. Turn off the ignitions of wrecked vehicles.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when turning left on which of the following traffic signals?
questions.answerA: A solid green light
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerC: A green arrow pointing left
questions.explanation: A green steady arrow means you may pass through the intersection in the direction that the arrow is pointing. Oncoming traffic is required to stop for turning traffic.

questions.question: Littering:
questions.answerA: Is against the law.
questions.answerB: May cause a traffic accident.
questions.answerC: Can lead to a $1,000 fine and up to one year in jail.
questions.explanation: Littering is against the law. It is unsightly and may cause a traffic accident. For example, a lit cigarette thrown out of your car window can be blown into the vehicle behind you, causing property damage or personal injury. If a judge finds you guilty of littering, you may have to pay up to a $1,000 fine and/or spend up to one year in jail.

questions.question: Taking drugs along with alcohol:
questions.answerA: Increases the risk of causing a crash.
questions.answerB: Is no more dangerous than consuming alcohol by itself.
questions.answerC: Lessens the effect of alcohol on your ability to drive.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your general driving ability.
questions.explanation: Drugs (including illegal, prescription, and over-the-counter medications) can affect your brain function and impair your ability to drive safely. Combining alcohol with other drugs will increase the risk of a crash.

questions.question: It is important to be alert to motorcycles because:
questions.answerA: They are more difficult to see than cars.
questions.answerB: They rarely use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Motorcyclists are less skilled drivers than other motorists.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and harder to see than cars. Because of their size, they are easily hidden in a car’s blind spot. It may be difficult to judge your distance to a motorcycle and difficult to tell how fast a motorcycle is moving, so always be alert and extra cautious when near a motorcyclist.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle if the line dividing your lane from the lane you wish to enter is a ____ line.
questions.answerA: Broken white
questions.answerB: Double solid yellow
questions.answerC: Solid yellow
questions.explanation: White lines separate traffic lanes traveling in the same direction. You may cross broken white lines to pass, as long as the passing lane is clear.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerA: Don’t make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: To reduce the effects of headlight glare at night, you should look:
questions.answerA: Straight ahead.
questions.answerB: Over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: At the center of the road
questions.answerD: To the right edge of the road.
questions.explanation: If oncoming drivers do not dim their headlights for you, keep your eyes on the right side of the road ahead. Do not look directly at the oncoming headlights because the glare may blind you for several seconds.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding seat belts and child restraints in vehicles?
questions.answerA: You should never place an infant or small child in the front seat of a vehicle with airbags.
questions.answerB: An airbag can be dangerous to an infant or small child, even in a low-speed collision.
questions.answerC: You should always make sure all your passengers are using a seat belt or child restraint.
questions.explanation: Before you drive, always fasten your seat belt and make sure all your passengers are using seat belts or child restraints. Studies have shown that if you use seat belts, your chances of being hurt or killed in a traffic crash are greatly reduced. Children age 12 and under should always ride properly restrained in a rear seat. Never put a rear-facing infant restraint in the front seat of a vehicle with a front passenger airbag.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Accelerate as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Back up slowly.
questions.answerD: Not move until another driver waves you on.
questions.explanation: A green light tells you that you can go through the intersection. However, you must first yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerA: Changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerB: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerC: Dangerous curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers to be extra careful when the pavement is wet because the road may become slippery, making vehicles more difficult to control.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerA: Changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: When getting ready to change lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your side view mirror.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn your head to check for other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Just before you begin moving into the other lane, quickly glance over your shoulder and check for any vehicles that may be in your blind spot.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: To be safe when crossing a railroad, you should:
questions.answerA: Look both ways, but only when the red light is flashing.
questions.answerB: Listen, look both ways, and then proceed if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Cross especially quickly when a train is approaching.
questions.answerD: Quickly pass under any lowering gates.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should look and listen for an approaching train coming from either direction before proceeding across the tracks. Watch for signals indicating an approaching train and never proceed until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Regulatory signs:
questions.answerA: Are placed in every location where there is a present danger.
questions.answerB: Indicate what a driver must or must not do.
questions.answerC: Are diamond-shaped and yellow or green.
questions.answerD: May warn drivers that they are approaching a school zone.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are often rectangular and white with black markings and are used to indicate what things a driver must or must not do in a designated area. They may display speed limits, prohibit passing or turning, or clarify any other driving regulation.

questions.question: Front door windows on a vehicle may be tinted to no more than:
questions.answerA: 100 percent light blockage.
questions.answerB: Whatever looks good.
questions.answerC: 65 percent light blockage.
questions.explanation: Tinting or sun-screening material is permitted on side and rear windows. Front door windows may be tinted to no more than 65 percent light blockage.

questions.question: If you are convicted of Driving While Intoxicated (DWI) for the second time in a five-year period, you will:
questions.answerA: Lose your license for only 90 days.
questions.answerB: Be restricted to drivng on residential roadways.
questions.answerC: Be required to install an Ignition Interlock Device (IID).
questions.answerD: Be required to drive 10 mph under the speed limit at all times.
questions.explanation: When convicted of a DWI, a driver who is above the age of 21 faces both administrative and court-convicted consequences. A second conviction within a five-year period may result in license suspension for one year, license denial for five years, a fee of $1,000, and/or up to one year of jail time. A second conviction will require an IID to be installed before a license can be reinstated.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Take your foot of the gas.
questions.answerB: Do not immediately use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Gradually slow down and pull off the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, take your foot off the gas pedal and do not immediately apply the brakes. Gradually slow down before gently applying the brakes and pulling off the side of the road.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerB: Curves ahead.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: A divided highway ends.
questions.answerB: A one-way street begins.
questions.answerC: A one-way street ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead becomes a divided highway. Keep to the right of the divider or median.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turns.
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A point accumulation advisory letter will be sent to you if you:
questions.answerA: Have too many points taken off of your driving record.
questions.answerB: Accumulate a total of four points in 12 months.
questions.answerC: Do not score enough points on your driving test.
questions.explanation: If you accumulate a total of four points within 12 months, you will be sent a point accumulation advisory letter. If you accumulate a total of eight or more points within 18 months, your driving privileges will be suspended.

questions.question: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver must produce:
questions.answerA: Proof of insurance.
questions.answerB: Their license.
questions.answerC: Proof of registration.
questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver is responsible for producing their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle when it is being driven.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerA: A rectangular red sign.
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merging traffic.
questions.answerB: Multiple turns.
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Wave your arms.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: Before switching on the ignition, you should:
questions.answerA: Be sure only backseat passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerB: Be sure only adult passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerC: Be sure only child passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerD: Be sure all of the vehicle's occupants have buckled their seat belts.
questions.explanation: Develop a routine for entering and leaving your car. Before switching on the ignition, buckle your safety belt and see that all passengers do likewise.

questions.question: The “No zone” is:
questions.answerA: A term used to describe blind spots around a truck or bus.
questions.answerB: A special speed zone.
questions.answerC: A roadway with restrictions on vehicle stereo volume.
questions.answerD: The television show that replaced The Twilight Zone.
questions.explanation: A truck or bus has blind spots on each side, in the rear, and in the front. An automobile cannot be seen in these blind spots. These blind spots are referred to as the “No zone.”

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerA: Entrance to full parking lots.
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: Emergency vehicles:
questions.answerA: Have the right-of-way when using sirens, horns, and/or flashing lights.
questions.answerB: May use a loudspeaker to give instructions.
questions.answerC: May follow each other.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to police cars, fire engines, ambulances, or any other emergency vehicles using a siren or air horn and a red or blue flashing light. Follow any instructions given over the emergency vehicles' loudspeakers. Emergency vehicles often follow each other so you should proceed only when you are certain the way is clear.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerA: On a hill or curve.
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: Braking distance is affected by:
questions.answerA: The speed your vehicle is traveling.
questions.answerB: The condition of your brakes and tires.
questions.answerC: The condition of the pavement.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect braking distance include how fast your vehicle is traveling, the condition of your brakes and tires, and the condition of the pavement.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerA: Tomato juice and lime
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: The minimum age a person must be in order to obtain a motorcycle instruction permit is:
questions.answerA: 14 years old.
questions.answerB: 15 years old.
questions.answerC: 15 and one-half years old.
questions.explanation: You may apply for a motorcycle instruction permit to learn to operate a motorcycle. The minimum age you must be to be eligible to apply for a motorcycle instruction permit is 15 and one-half years old.

questions.question: You may drive across a dashed white line:
questions.answerA: At any time.
questions.answerB: Only during daylight hours.
questions.answerC: When it is safe to change lanes.
questions.explanation: Traffic lanes moving in the same direction are separated by broken white lines. You may cross over dashed lines to pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn.
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: FACT is an abbreviation for:
questions.answerA: Finance A Car Today.
questions.answerB: Full Ambulance Cannot Turn.
questions.answerC: Fear of Authority Causes Tension.
questions.answerD: Failure to Appear in Court for Traffic violations.
questions.explanation: FACT is an abbreviation for "Failure to Appear in Court for Traffic violations." When you fail to appear in court for a traffic violation, the court will notify you within 10 days of your failure to comply. Failure to comply will result in suspension of your license.

questions.question: In Missouri, it is illegal for an adult driver to operate a motor vehicle with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: In Missouri, it is illegal for a driver age 21 or older to operate a motor vehicle with a BAC of 0.08 percent or more. It is illegal for a driver under the age of 21 to operate a motor vehicle with a BAC of 0.02 percent or more. Being convicted of Driving While Intoxicated (DWI) may result license suspension or revocation.

questions.question: Before entering a roundabout, you must slow down and yield to:
questions.answerA: Vehicles in the roundabout.
questions.answerB: Bicyclists in the roundabout.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians in the roundabout.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and vehicles that are already in the roundabout.

questions.question: You must keep proof of your liability insurance:
questions.answerA: At your place of employment.
questions.answerB: In a safety deposit box at the bank.
questions.answerC: In your vehicle whenever it is being operated.
questions.explanation: State law requires all motor vehicle operators and owners to have a form of liability insurance. You must keep proof of insurance in your vehicle. If a law enforcement officer asks you for proof and you cannot show it, you will receive a ticket.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.answerD: Be alert for construction workers on the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. Drivers should be cautious when driving where pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: Before turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your signal.
questions.answerB: Turn the wheel.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should activate your turn signal three to four seconds before your turn.

questions.question: At night, it is hardest to see:
questions.answerA: Road signs.
questions.answerB: Pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Other motorists.
questions.explanation: Compared to signs and other roadside objects, pedestrians are hardest to see at night.

questions.question: Pennant-shaped signs indicate:
questions.answerA: School zones.
questions.answerB: No passing zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs usually indicate no passing zones. Text will also be on the sign to confirm that it is a no passing zone.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: Which of the following best ensures your safety and the safety of those around you when you are backing your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Honk your horn right before shifting into reverse.
questions.answerB: Check behind the vehicle before you get into the driver's seat.
questions.answerC: Check your rearview mirrors to see what is behind you.
questions.answerD: Turn up the car radio before backing up to get the attention of anyone who may be around you.
questions.explanation: Backing requires extra caution because it is difficult for drivers to see behind their vehicles. Before entering a vehicle to back up, walk to the back of the vehicle to check for children and small objects.

questions.question: To ensure that your physical condition does not cause you to drive in an unsafe manner, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep physically fit and have regular physical examinations.
questions.answerB: Know the effect of any medicine on your driving ability.
questions.answerC: Drive within your physical limitations.
questions.explanation: Your physical condition has an important bearing on your ability to drive safely. Drivers should be aware of their physical limitations and only drive if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a steep downhill grade is ahead.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Turn right after making a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Right turns are not permitted.
questions.answerC: Left turns are permitted.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs display laws that drivers must always obey. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is present.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle’s right wheels leave the pavement?
questions.answerA: Stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Immediately pull all the way off of the road and get back on when it is safe.
questions.answerC: Accelerate and steer back on the road quickly.
questions.answerD: Take your foot off the accelerator, slow down, then ease back onto the road when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle’s right wheels leave the pavement, don't panic. Take your foot off the accelerator and steer parallel to the road. Slow down and ease back onto the roadway by keeping both hands on the steering wheel and steering into the road’s right lane with a small turn of the steering wheel. Check for traffic around you before steering back onto the pavement.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerA: Larger blind spots.
questions.answerB: Smaller blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential bicycle cross traffic.

questions.question: When faced with an oncoming car to the left and a bicyclist to the right, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull onto the shoulder.
questions.answerB: Split the difference.
questions.answerC: Let the car pass and then pass the bike.
questions.explanation: When there is more than one potential hazard on the road, you should ensure that you only have to deal with one of them at a time. For example, when there is a bicyclist on the right that you want to pass and an oncoming car to the left, you should not try to squeeze between both at the same time. Instead, let the oncoming car pass, and then pass the bicyclist.

questions.question: Downward-facing triangular signs:
questions.answerA: Indicate school zones.
questions.answerB: Tell drivers to yield.
questions.answerC: Indicate construction zones.
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs usually indicate that drivers should yield. Once the road is clear of traffic or pedestrians and it is safe to do so, drivers may proceed.

questions.question: Shortly before your driver or nondriver license expires, the Driver License Bureau will mail a renewal reminder postcard to:
questions.answerA: The most current address on your driver record.
questions.answerB: The address on your last application.
questions.answerC: The address in your local phone book.
questions.explanation: The department will mail you a reminder to renew before your license expires. The reminder will be sent to the mailing address on your driver record. A renewal notice will not be mailed for a temporary instruction permit or commercial learner’s permit.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing yellow light. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for the light to change.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn because the intersection is closed.
questions.answerC: Drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Prepare to stop; the light is about to turn red.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should proceed through the intersection slowly and with caution. Scan your eyes across traffic in both directions.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: When you see this black and yellow sign, it means:
questions.answerA: The road to the right is for one-way traffic only.
questions.answerB: That due to upcoming roadwork, there is a detour to the right.
questions.answerC: Slow down because the road ahead changes direction at an extreme angle.
questions.answerD: There is a crossroad to your right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead changes direction at an extreme angle (in this case, to the right). Before you reach such an extreme curve, you should slow down as much as you would when making a turn at an intersection.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Begin signaling as you move into the next lane.
questions.answerC: Signal at least 500 feet before your lane change when driving on residential streets.
questions.explanation: Other cars and motorcycles are often hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot, so be sure to glance over your shoulder before you begin a lane change. Begin signaling 100 feet before changing lanes or turning in a residential area. Signal five seconds in advance when changing lanes on a freeway.

questions.question: Certain highway signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerA: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Failure to comply is subject to penalty.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerB: A steep grade is ahead.
questions.answerC: The overpass ahead has a low clearance.
questions.answerD: Two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are about to merge.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. Do not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height indicated (in this case, 13 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: You should be cautious when passing a bicycle because:
questions.answerA: You are moving faster than the bicycle.
questions.answerB: The bicycle always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic may not see you pull out to pass the bicycle.
questions.answerD: The cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road.
questions.explanation: You should always be cautious when passing a bicycle because the cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road. Always be particularly careful when driving near bicyclists.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: When in a travel lane on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You may stop to drop off passengers.
questions.answerB: You may stop to look up an address.
questions.answerC: You may make a U-turn or back up if you get on the wrong entrance ramp of the freeway.
questions.answerD: Don’t stop for any reason. Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.
questions.explanation: You should not stop in a travel lane for any reason. Instead, keep moving until you can safely pull off of the road. If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up. Go to the next turn or exit or where you can safely turn around.

questions.question: To check your blind spot before changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Look into the left side mirror.
questions.answerB: Look into the right side mirror.
questions.answerC: Look into the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot before changing lanes, you should look over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: When sharing the road with a truck, it is important to remember that trucks generally:
questions.answerA: Require longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerB: Require less time to pass on a downgrade than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerC: Require a smaller turning radius than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerD: Require less time to pass on an incline than smaller vehicles do.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, trucks need longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.

questions.question: When you see or hear an emergency vehicle coming, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately and let the vehicle pass.
questions.answerB: Drive as far toward the right side of the road as is safe and stop.
questions.answerC: Proceed slowly and permit the vehicle to pass.
questions.answerD: Keep moving slowly, staying to the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: When driving on a two-lane roadway or undivided highway, you must yield to an emergency vehicle using its lights and/or siren, regardless of the direction from which it is approaching. Immediately drive as near as possible to the right side of the road and stop, taking care not to stop within an intersection.

questions.question: Drive below the posted speed limit when:
questions.answerA: Anything makes conditions less than perfect.
questions.answerB: You see a police car.
questions.answerC: Entering a highway where there are other cars.
questions.answerD: You are on a four-lane road.
questions.explanation: When the road is wet or slippery, when you cannot see well, or when anything else makes conditions less than perfect, drive below the posted speed limit. Even if you are driving within the posted speed limit, you can still be ticketed for driving too fast for conditions.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Go the same speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerB: One-way traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you must keep to the right of the upcoming divider.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerD: Treat the light like a stop sign.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights are used at dangerous intersections. Treat them like stop signs.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Overcorrect.
questions.answerB: Turn your steering wheel into traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel in the direction you want to go.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, remain calm. Steer in the direction that you want to go and try not to overcorrect.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks only.
questions.answerB: Trucks are entering the highway.
questions.answerC: Upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that drivers are approaching a steep hill and should prepare to adjust their speeds to continue to drive safely.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerB: Move to the left lane.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: Your blind spot is the area of the road:
questions.answerA: You cannot see without moving your head.
questions.answerB: Directly behind your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You see in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: You see in your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see without moving their head. They can be located to the sides of and behind a vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Curve ahead.
questions.answerB: Roadwork ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming curve in the road.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: Before changing lanes on a multilane highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should look in your rearview and side mirrors to make sure no one is trying to pass you. You should also look over your shoulder to make sure that no one is in your blind spot.

questions.question: You must stop for a school bus:
questions.answerA: That is parked on the shoulder of the road with no one in it.
questions.answerB: When it approaches you, even if its lights are not flashing.
questions.answerC: If you are both driving on a two-lane highway and its red lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: Whenever the driver waves at you.
questions.explanation: You must stop when approaching a school bus that is displaying flashing red lights while stopped to pick up or drop off children. On a two-lane road, traffic moving in both directions must stop and remain stopped as long as the red lights near the top of the bus are flashing and/or the stop arm on the left side of the bus is extended.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerA: Turn left.
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: While driving on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you encounter a bicyclist traveling in the same direction. What is the safest way to pass the bicyclist?
questions.answerA: Slow down and wait until there is no traffic approaching, then pass the bicyclist while leaving him or her sufficient space.
questions.answerB: Continue driving straight. It is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
questions.answerC: Do not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
questions.answerD: Honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.
questions.explanation: You should pass a bicyclist the same way you would pass any other vehicle, but not so fast or close to them that you throw debris in their face or blow them around with the draft of air from your vehicle. Allow at least 3 feet of space between your side mirror and the bicyclist, or at least 5 feet on higher speed roads or when there is a group of bicyclists. Honking unnecessarily may startle riders and make them more likely to crash.

questions.question: You may continue carefully through an intersection with a yellow light if:
questions.answerA: There is an emergency vehicle crossing your lane.
questions.answerB: There are pedestrians crossing.
questions.answerC: You are turning right.
questions.answerD: You are already within the intersection when the light changes to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a steady yellow light appears when you are already within an intersection, you should continue through the intersection carefully.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: Drink coffee.
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: You are driving at night and another vehicle is approaching from the opposite direction. Your headlights:
questions.answerA: Should be on their high beam setting.
questions.answerB: Should be on their low beam setting.
questions.answerC: Should be off. Use your parking lights.
questions.answerD: May be on either their high or low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Do not use your high beam headlights when approaching or following another vehicle at night. Switch to the low beam setting to ensure the safety of everyone on the road.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Eating, drinking, or smoking.
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: When approaching a steady red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop only if a police officer is nearby.
questions.explanation: A steady red traffic light indicates that drivers must come to a complete stop. Driving through a red light is against the law and is extremely dangerous. Drivers may turn right on a steady red light if there is no sign prohibiting a turn on red.

questions.question: When passing a large vehicle, the driver of a small vehicle must be prepared for:
questions.answerA: Loud noises.
questions.answerB: Excess air pollution.
questions.answerC: Wind gusts produced by the large vehicle.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles can cause wind gusts with a force great enough to cause direction changes in smaller vehicles. Drivers of small vehicles should be prepared to take proper corrective steering action when approaching or passing large vehicles that are moving at or near maximum speeds.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: A license will be suspended if a driver:
questions.answerA: Refuses to submit to a chemical test.
questions.answerB: Drives 10 mph over the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Honks their horn in a residential area after midnight.
questions.answerD: Does not turn off their high beam lights around another vehicle.
questions.explanation: By operating a vehicle on Missouri roadways, a driver automatically consents to taking a chemical test to determine their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) when requested by an officer. If a driver refuses the test, their license will be suspended for one year.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: No passing zone
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: You are stopped in a line of vehicles waiting at a stop sign. If there is no cross traffic after the vehicles ahead have passed through the intersection, you:
questions.answerA: May proceed through the intersection without stopping again.
questions.answerB: Must stop again at the stop sign or stop line before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May slowly roll past the stop sign.
questions.answerD: May follow the vehicle directly ahead of you without stopping.
questions.explanation: You must always bring your vehicle to a complete stop and yield to approaching traffic before proceeding past a stop sign. Don't feel pressured by surrounding traffic to avoid making a complete stop.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Limit your driving to weekdays.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: If you are at fault in a traffic crash and do not pay for the damages:
questions.answerA: Your driver license and/or plates will be suspended for one year.
questions.answerB: You will save money.
questions.answerC: Your car will be repossessed.
questions.answerD: You must buy a new car.
questions.explanation: If you are at fault in an accident and do not pay for the damages you caused, your driver license and/or vehicle license plates will be suspended for one year. You may have your license and plates reinstated during that one-year period if you pay a fee and provide proof that you have settled damages.

questions.question: A leaky exhaust system in your vehicle is dangerous because it can cause:
questions.answerA: A loss of hearing.
questions.answerB: Pollution.
questions.answerC: Carbon monoxide poisoning.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system carries exhaust gas out of the vehicle and prevents fumes from entering into the passenger compartment. To prevent carbon monoxide poisoning, keep your exhaust system free of leaks. Replace all defective parts immediately.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means that you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with care.
questions.answerB: Continue normally through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed when a green light appears.
questions.answerD: Stop and proceed when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means "caution." If you approach such a light, slow down, look, and proceed with care.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: Your vehicle strikes an unattended parked vehicle and you cannot locate the vehicle’s owner. You:
questions.answerA: Have done as much as you can.
questions.answerB: Must stay until the police arrive.
questions.answerC: Must leave a written notice containing your name, your address, and the circumstances of the accident.
questions.explanation: Upon striking an unattended vehicle, stop and try to locate the owner. If you cannot find the owner, leave a written notice containing your name, your address, and the circumstances of the accident.

questions.question: Which of the following lights indicates that you should slow down and proceed with caution at an intersection?
questions.answerA: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerB: A flashing red light
questions.answerC: A solid yellow light
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light at an intersection indicates that drivers must slow down, proceed with caution, and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: ____ limit your concentration, perception, judgment, and memory.
questions.answerA: Only a blood alcohol level greater than the legal limit can
questions.answerB: Alcohol does not
questions.answerC: Even the smallest amount of alcohol can
questions.answerD: Only a blood alcohol level greater than 0.05 percent can
questions.explanation: Even the smallest amount of alcohol will reduce your concentration, perception, judgment and memory, and your driving skills will suffer. No one can drink and drive safely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to slow down.
questions.answerB: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and, if necessary, yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This type of triangular sign means drivers must yield. You must slow down as you come to an intersection marked with this sign and be prepared to stop. Let any other vehicles, bicyclists, or pedestrians pass safely before you proceed.

questions.question: At an intersection with a stop sign, you should stop and:
questions.answerA: Check your rearview mirror for cars tailgating.
questions.answerB: Move when the vehicle ahead of you moves.
questions.answerC: Look right first, then left, then right again.
questions.answerD: Look left first, then right, then left again.
questions.explanation: When stopped at an intersection, you should first look to your left, as vehicles coming from the left are closer to you than vehicles coming from the right. Look to your right, then look to your left again, in case there are any vehicles coming from that direction that you did not see at first glance.

questions.question: Where should you go to take the Missouri driver examinations?
questions.answerA: Any Missouri State Highway Patrol examination station.
questions.answerB: Any Department of Transportation office.
questions.answerC: Any Missouri contract office.
questions.answerD: The nearest high school driver education class.
questions.explanation: The Missouri State Highway Patrol (MSHP) administers the driver examination. To find the testing center nearest you, contact the MSHP or the Department of Revenue.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stopped with its stop arm extended, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and wait to proceed.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn before passing the bus on its left.
questions.answerC: Continue driving when they think most kids are probably done exiting the bus.
questions.answerD: Pass the bus before its door opens.
questions.explanation: When approaching a stopped school bus that is using its stop signal, a driver is required to come to a complete stop. They should not proceed until the stop arm is withdrawn.

questions.question: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means:
questions.answerA: Passing on the left is permitted from either direction.
questions.answerB: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken line.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid line.
questions.answerD: Passing is not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that passing is allowed from the lane on the side next to the broken line.

questions.question: If you are convicted of Driving While Intoxicated (DWI) for the first time, you will:
questions.answerA: Lose your license for 90 days.
questions.answerB: Be fined $50.
questions.answerC: Be required to install an Ignition Interlock Device (IID).
questions.explanation: When convicted of a DWI, a driver who is above the age of 21 faces both administrative and court-convicted consequences. A first-time conviction will result in an administrative license suspension for 90 days. A court conviction could result in a six-month jail sentence and a $500 fine. Penalties increase with subsequent offenses.

questions.question: In which of the following ways can alcoholic beverages affect you?
questions.answerA: It slows your reaction time.
questions.answerB: It gives you a feeling of false confidence.
questions.answerC: It impairs your thinking ability.
questions.explanation: Alcohol dulls the parts of your brain that control inhibition, judgment, and self-control. As a result, you may feel stimulated, lively, and a bit giddy or foolish after consuming alcohol. Alcohol also impairs your reaction time, coordination, and balance. Your vision and ability to judge distance suffers after alcohol consumption, making it difficult to react to your surroundings.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerA: Turn left.
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: When you are in a line of traffic that is crossing a railroad track that has no signals or gates:
questions.answerA: You have the right-of-way and do not need to check for trains.
questions.answerB: You may pass slower drivers while crossing the track.
questions.answerC: You need to make sure there is space for your vehicle to get all the way across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: If you are following another vehicle at a railroad crossing, check to make sure you have enough room to get all the way across before you drive onto the tracks. You should never try to pass another vehicle as you approach or cross a railroad crossing. Always check for trains before crossing any railroad tracks.

questions.question: What are the colors of signs that tell you the distance to the next exit on a highway?
questions.answerA: Yellow with black letters
questions.answerB: Black with white letters
questions.answerC: Red with white letters
questions.explanation: Signs providing information about destinations are green with white letters or symbols.

questions.question: You are driving in the left lane and want to move into the right lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your left shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your right shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over both shoulders for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors, signal, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you should check your vehicle's blind spots by looking over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move. Always check your mirrors and turn on your directional signal before beginning a lane change.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerA: An intersection.
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Littering:
questions.answerA: Is against the law.
questions.answerB: May cause a traffic accident.
questions.answerC: Can lead to a $1,000 fine and up to one year in jail.
questions.explanation: Littering is against the law. It is unsightly and may cause a traffic accident. For example, a lit cigarette thrown out of your car window can be blown into the vehicle behind you, causing property damage or personal injury. If a judge finds you guilty of littering, you may have to pay up to a $1,000 fine and/or spend up to one year in jail.

questions.question: When parking uphill next to a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Keep the rear tires against the curb.
questions.answerB: Keep the front tires straight ahead.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel away from the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn your steering wheel toward the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street that has a curb, set your parking brake and turn your steering wheel away from the curb. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll, it will roll into the curb.

questions.question: What does alcohol do to your driving skills and judgement?
questions.answerA: It helps driving skills but harms your judgement.
questions.answerB: It harms both driving skills and judgement.
questions.answerC: It has no effect on either driving skills or judgement.
questions.answerD: It has no effect on judgement but it harms driving skills.
questions.explanation: Alcohol negatively affects many skills needed for safe driving, including your reaction time and ability to see clearly. It can also harm your judgment of speed and distance, lower your inhibitions, and make you more prone to taking chances.

questions.question: After stopping for a school bus that is unloading children:
questions.answerA: Do not proceed until the children wave to you.
questions.answerB: Watch for children walking along the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: After stopping for a school bus that has its stop arm extended and its lights flashing, watch for children walking along the side of the road. You should always drive with caution when driving near children.

questions.question: A person's ability to drive can be impaired by:
questions.answerA: Alcohol.
questions.answerB: Any medication.
questions.answerC: A lack of sleep.
