questions.explanation: When intending to back up, always check behind your vehicle before getting in. Children and small objects are difficult to see from the driver’s seat. While backing, turn your head so you can see through the rear window. Do not depend only on your mirrors or sensors.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerB: Keep driving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn right.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: All traffic must go straight ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection ahead. A road joins from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Lane ends.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: Allowing a space cushion between your vehicle and its surroundings is important because it:
questions.answerA: Prevents distractions from other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Allows you time to react to unexpected situations.
questions.answerC: Keeps traffic flowing at a safe pace.
questions.explanation: The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you.

questions.question: Where should you go to take the Missouri driver examinations?
questions.answerA: Any Missouri State Highway Patrol examination station.
questions.answerB: Any Department of Transportation office.
questions.answerC: Any Missouri contract office.
questions.answerD: The nearest high school driver education class.
questions.explanation: The Missouri State Highway Patrol (MSHP) administers the driver examination. To find the testing center nearest you, contact the MSHP or the Department of Revenue.

questions.question: To let others know that you want to be an organ donor, you should:
questions.answerA: Complete the organ donor information on the back of your license.
questions.answerB: Discuss your decision with your next of kin.
questions.answerC: Have two witnesses sign the back of your license.
questions.explanation: To ensure your decision to be an organ donor, either enroll online or in person when applying for or renewing your permit or license. Completely fill out the back of your permit or license and inform your family.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: When making a right turn on a green light, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your normal driving speed.
questions.answerB: Stop and look for nearby police cars.
questions.answerC: Yield to pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right or left at a steady green light. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: If you see this sign above your lane, you:
questions.answerA: May not exit the freeway.
questions.answerB: May either continue through the interchange or exit the freeway from your current lane.
questions.answerC: May stay in your lane and continue through the interchange.
questions.answerD: Must exit the freeway, if you stay in your current lane.
questions.explanation: If a yellow panel with the message "Exit only" is on a highway sign, the lane below the sign will not continue through the interchange. Instead, the lane will go off of the roadway to form a ramp. If you are in a lane directly under an "Exit only" sign, you may change lanes to move through the interchange or you must exit the highway.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerB: Pull off the right side of the road and let traffic pass.
questions.answerC: Not let the other cars pass your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: When you are being tailgated:
questions.answerA: Move over to the right, if there is an open lane to your right.
questions.answerB: If there is not an open lane to your right, wait until the way is clear ahead and reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerC: Never slow down abruptly.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated by another driver and there is a right lane, move over to the right. If there is no right lane, wait until the road ahead is clear and then reduce your speed slowly. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you. Never slow down abruptly as this will only increase the risk of your vehicle being hit from behind.

questions.question: The minimum and maximum speed limits on Missouri interstate highways are:
questions.answerA: 40 mph and 55 mph.
questions.answerB: 40 mph and 70 mph.
questions.answerC: 30 mph and 70 mph.
questions.explanation: You may never drive at speeds faster than 70 mph on Missouri's interstate highways. You may not drive more slowly than 40 mph on interstate highways, under normal roadway conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn.
questions.answerB: No stopping.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver cuts you off, you should:
questions.answerA: Call the police immediately.
questions.answerB: Stay calm and move out of the aggressive driver's way.
questions.answerC: Flash your vehicle's lights to let the aggressive driver know he is wrong.
questions.answerD: Use a driving action of your own to get back at the aggressive driver.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver cuts you off on the roadway, stay calm and get out of their way. Trying to get even with an aggressive driver risks escalating the situation and increasing the danger.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Intersection ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign means that you are approaching an upcoming intersection. Watch carefully for cross traffic.

questions.question: The effect that alcohol has on your reflexes and judgment:
questions.answerA: Is less pronounced when consuming beer instead of wine.
questions.answerB: Is less pronounced when consuming wine instead of beer.
questions.answerC: Is most pronounced when consuming hard ciders and mixed drinks.
questions.answerD: Depends on the amount of alcohol in your bloodstream.
questions.explanation: Consuming any type of alcohol can have negative effects on your reflexes and judgment. It does not matter which type of alcohol is consumed, only how much alcohol has entered a person's bloodstream.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: The highway ahead curves only to the right.
questions.answerB: The highway ahead turns sharply to the right.
questions.answerC: The highway ahead curves to the right and then to the left.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead curves to the left and then to the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: Points:
questions.answerA: Are nothing to worry about.
questions.answerB: Are a good thing to have on your driving record.
questions.answerC: Are helpful if you want to get a job driving.
questions.answerD: Are something you don’t want on your driving record.
questions.explanation: When you are convicted of a traffic violation while your vehicle is in motion, the department receives notice and adds points to your driving record. You can lose your driving privilege when you accumulate too many points.

questions.question: A good defensive driver:
questions.answerA: Drives slowly at all times.
questions.answerB: Looks out for the actions of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Travels at a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even the most experienced drivers can be distracted while driving. A defensive driver looks out for the actions of other drivers and anticipates potential problems.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks are permitted on an upcoming narrow bridge.
questions.answerB: The bridge ahead is open to one-way traffic only.
questions.answerC: The bridge ahead is wide enough for only one car at a time.
questions.answerD: The bridge ahead may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that an upcoming bridge may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck and that they should be careful.

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
questions.explanation: Consuming both alcohol and another drug may enhance the effects of both. For example, taking one drink when you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as if you have had several drinks.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle by using the shoulder of the road:
questions.answerA: When the vehicle in front of you is making a left turn.
questions.answerB: To go around a slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: When the traffic ahead is blocked for up to 250 feet.
questions.explanation: Never pass on the shoulder. Other drivers will not expect you to be there and may pull off the road without looking.

questions.question: Pentagonal signs indicate:
questions.answerA: No passing zones.
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in a school zone. Be extra alert to children and pedestrians when driving near a school.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: When approaching a steady yellow traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate to avoid a red light.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Slow to a stop, unless they are already within the intersection.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that a red light is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Keep right.
questions.answerB: Low shoulder.
questions.answerC: No parking at any time.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: What can you do to avoid the need to make emergency stops while driving in traffic?
questions.answerA: Honk your horn to make others aware of your presence.
questions.answerB: Look ahead and maintain a safe following distance.
questions.answerC: Drive in the right lane only.
questions.answerD: Drive more slowly than the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Keeping a safe following distance will enable you to react to an upcoming problem without the need for a emergency stop, which could cause a driver behind you to crash into the back of your vehicle.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when:
questions.answerA: Driving behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision.
questions.answerB: Exiting an expressway.
questions.answerC: Following a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should increase your following distance when you are behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision, when driving in bad weather or heavy traffic, when exiting an expressway, when behind a motorcycle or bicycle, and if someone is tailgating you.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Low clearance.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be aware of potential traffic entering from an upcoming side road.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Continue at your current speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: Vehicle stopping distances never depend on:
questions.answerA: Your own reaction time.
questions.answerB: The time of day.
questions.answerC: The condition of your vehicle's brakes.
questions.answerD: The condition and type of your vehicle's tires.
questions.explanation: The distance that a vehicle needs to stop depends on the motorist's reaction time, weather and visibility conditions, the vehicle's weight, the conditions of the vehicle's brakes, the condition and type of the vehicle's tires, roadway conditions, and speed.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: Certain highway signs contain information about hazardous conditions. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerA: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Warning signs advise drivers of potentially hazardous conditions. For your own safety, obey warning signs. Disregarding the information provided by a warning sign may result in an accident due to your negligence.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Minimum speed limit.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. Wherever this regulation sign is posted, U-turns are not permitted.

questions.question: Which is not a factor in determining the distance that it takes to stop your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Steering ability
questions.answerB: Braking distance
questions.answerC: Reaction distance
questions.explanation: The distance required to stop your vehicle depends on perception time, reaction distance, and braking distance. This changes with speed and road conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks under 18,000 lbs. allowed.
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill ahead.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: When driving on slick roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Take turns more slowly than usual.
questions.answerB: Change lanes quickly.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: While it is always dangerous to drive too fast on slippery roads, this is especially true when driving in turns and curves. Be sure to approach them more slowly in slippery conditions than you would under normal circumstances.

questions.question: When a person buys a vehicle, they must title the vehicle within:
questions.answerA: 30 days.
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.answerC: One week.
questions.explanation: When you buy a vehicle, you must apply for a title within 30 days. If you do not apply within 30 days, you will have to pay a penalty fee.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you operate a motor vehicle while intoxicated and you injure or kill another person, you:
questions.answerA: Will only have to pay a fine.
questions.answerB: Will only spend time in jail.
questions.answerC: Will only lose your license.
questions.answerD: May lose your license and be sentenced to jail.
questions.explanation: Operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated is both illegal and dangerous. If you are driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol and you cause an accident that injures or kills another person, you may be sentenced to two to seven years in jail, be required to pay a $5,000 fine, and lose your license for five years.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Fire station.
questions.answerC: T intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming traffic signal. They should be prepared to respond to a yellow light, red light, and/or cross traffic.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerA: The maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: On a road which has no sidewalks, a pedestrian should walk on the:
questions.answerA: Side of the road which has the lightest traffic.
questions.answerB: Same side of the road on which traffic is moving.
questions.answerC: Side of the road facing oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Side of the road which has the heaviest traffic.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk on the side of the road facing the traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Curves ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: This sign warns drivers that the divided highway ends ahead.

questions.question: If one of your tires blows out as you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard immediately.
questions.answerB: Try to steer straight while gradually slowing by removing your foot from the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Maintain your current speed and steer straight.
questions.answerD: Swerve back and forth to alert traffic behind you.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the car headed straight down the road. Ease your foot off the gas pedal and do not apply the brakes until you have complete control. When the car is under control, brake gently and pull off the road at the nearest safe location.

questions.question: When you hear a fire engine siren behind you, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive with your flashers on.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and stop.
questions.answerD: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren of an emergency vehicle, you must pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection when the traffic light changes from green to solid yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Consider it the same as a caution sign and continue through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, unless you are too close to stop safely.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get through the intersection before the red light appears.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a solid yellow traffic light, slow to a stop before entering the intersection, if it is safe to do so. If you can't stop safely, drive carefully through the intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Left turn yield on green.
questions.explanation: This sign means that a traffic signal is ahead. You should slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that pavement is slippery when wet. In wet conditions, you should reduce your speed, avoid braking or changing direction suddenly, and increase the distance between your vehicle and the one ahead.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Presence of a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Driving while being distracted by any activity:
questions.answerA: Is never dangerous.
questions.answerB: Usually causes the driver to react more slowly to hazards.
questions.answerC: Usually causes the driver to drive faster.
questions.answerD: Is only dangerous for young drivers.
questions.explanation: Distractions cause drivers to react more slowly to traffic and hazards on the roadway. Distracted driving is never safe.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on an interstate expressway:
questions.answerA: Stop and make a U-turn.
questions.answerB: Get off at the next exit and come back to the exit you missed.
questions.answerC: Roll down your window and ask the driver next to you for help.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up or try to turn around on the highway. Go to the next exit and safely turn around.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions ahead of the lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Make sure the lane is clear before entering.
questions.explanation: Always signal for an appropriate amount of time before making a lane change or exiting a freeway. Before you make any move to the right or left, quickly turn your head and look over your shoulder to see if your blind spot is clear.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should adjust, if needed, when you get into a car to drive?
questions.answerA: Your seat belt
questions.answerB: The steering wheel
questions.answerC: Your rearview mirror
questions.explanation: When preparing to drive, you should first adjust your seat to ensure that you are in a comfortable position and can see the road clearly. Adjust your mirrors and steering wheel to be effective when your seat is fully adjusted.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Flash your lights.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the pedestrian cross.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop whenever you see pedestrians walking on or crossing the roadway. Be particularly careful where children are present. Always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing in a crosswalk.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: To help relieve fatigue on a long trip, it is a good idea to:
questions.answerA: Stop and rest every two hours.
questions.answerB: Do arm exercises every hour.
questions.answerC: Drive with one eye open at a time.
questions.answerD: Change feet on the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued while taking a long trip, stop every two hours for a short break. If you become drowsy, pull off the road and park in a safe place to take a nap, or find a room to stay for the night.

questions.question: Car drivers should know that large trucks:
questions.answerA: Have large blind spots.
questions.answerB: Can stop more quickly than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Do not need more room to maneuver than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: A large truck has large blind spots to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle. Avoid lingering in these areas. Because of their larger size and weight, trucks require more room to maneuver and stop than passenger vehicles.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: During daylight hours only.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot when:
questions.answerA: Pulling toward or away from a curb.
questions.answerB: Turning left or right.
questions.answerC: Changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot every time you want to change your vehicle's position. If you are turning, changing lanes, or pulling toward or away from a curb, you should check your blind spots.

questions.question: You come to an intersection displaying a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are also approaching the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop only if other cars are already within the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light has the same meaning as a stop sign. You must stop, yield the right-of-way, and go once it is safe.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: A speed restriction sign:
questions.answerA: May be ignored in rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.
questions.answerB: Has a triangular shape.
questions.answerC: Is blue with black lettering.
questions.answerD: Shows a recommended speed for a curve or turn.
questions.explanation: Curve and turn warning signs often have attached advisory speed signs that show a recommended driving speed for drivers in the curves and turns. Although a driver may feel comfortable driving at a higher speed in fair weather, they should never do so under rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: What does an orange-colored sign indicate?
questions.answerA: The start of a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: A railroad crossing is ahead.
questions.answerC: A school zone is ahead.
questions.explanation: Construction, maintenance, and emergency operations signs are generally orange with black symbols.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spots by:
questions.answerA: Using the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Using the outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using both inside and outside rearview mirrors.
questions.answerD: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should turn your head to check your blind spots before every lane change.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the tracks before the gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: Try to drive around a lowered gate.
questions.answerD: Not pay attention to how many tracks there are to cross.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks, you should look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop for trains or other vehicles that may be using the rails.

questions.question: Stress can affect your driving by:
questions.answerA: Lowing your ability to focus on driving.
questions.answerB: Decreasing your chances of an accident.
questions.answerC: Causing you to fall asleep at the wheel.
questions.answerD: Making you more aware of others around you.
questions.explanation: Emotions can have a great effect on your driving ability. You may not be able to drive well if you are overly worried, excited, afraid, angry, or sad. Stress can lessen your concentration on the task of driving. It is better to wait to drive than to risk driving while you are emotionally unstable.

questions.question: If a driver sees an animal on the roadway:
questions.answerA: No special action is required.
questions.answerB: The driver should honk their horn.
questions.answerC: The driver should pass the animal as closely as possible.
questions.answerD: The driver should be very cautious.
questions.explanation: Be very cautious any time you encounter an animal on the roadway. Pass the animal slowly to avoid startling or frightening it.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn.
questions.answerB: Turn right at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a crossroad ahead.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Go.
questions.answerB: Yield to other cars.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing warning sign:
questions.answerA: Be ready to drive faster than the train.
questions.answerB: Be prepared to stop if a train is nearby.
questions.answerC: Look for a way around any lowered gates.
questions.answerD: Assume no trains are nearby and continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossing warning signs are used to warn drivers of the possibility of a train. Drivers should obey all railroad crossing warning signs and never go around barriers or disregard the warning sign.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerA: Inattentive driving
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: You may not cross a single broken white or yellow line:
questions.answerA: When doing so would interfere with traffic.
questions.answerB: When turning left into a driveway.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is disabled.
questions.answerD: When passing to the right on a one-way street.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single broken line to pass or change lanes as long as you can do so safely and without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: You experience an incident at work that has left you feeling angry. When you get to your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Play the radio loudly so you won’t think about it.
questions.answerB: Drive fast on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.answerC: Take a few minutes to cool off before you begin your drive home.
questions.answerD: Stop at your favorite bar and have a few drinks before driving home.
questions.explanation: Persons who are upset, angry, or otherwise distracted by their emotions should take time to cool off before driving a car. Taking out frustrations or anger while driving is exercising very poor judgment and is very dangerous to both the driver and others on the road.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Very uncommon.
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: When the train has passed.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: When a stop is required at an intersection and no markings appear to indicate a stop line or crosswalk, a driver:
questions.answerA: Is not required to stop.
questions.answerB: Is required to slow down to make sure crossing traffic is clear.
questions.answerC: Should stop only at a place where they can see at least 200 feet on either side, even if they have to enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.answerD: Should stop where they have a clear view of approaching traffic before they enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.explanation: If there is no stop line or crosswalk, you should stop at the point nearest to the intersecting roadway where you can get a view of approaching traffic. You should not enter the intersecting roadway to gain a better view.

questions.question: When making a turn, you must ____ your speed.
questions.answerA: Increase
questions.answerB: Maintain
questions.answerC: Vary
questions.explanation: When turning, you should reduce to a speed that allows you to maintain control of your vehicle, stay in your lane, and react to unexpected situations.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in right lane must slow down.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: Merge.
questions.answerD: Pass only in the right lane.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a merge ahead. It warns that two lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are about to become one.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: A yellow and black diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns you about conditions on or near the road.
questions.answerB: Helps direct you to cities and towns ahead.
questions.answerC: Tells you about traffic laws and regulations.
questions.answerD: Tells you about road construction ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs, which tell you about conditions on or near the road ahead, are usually diamond-shaped with black symbols or words on a yellow background.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerA: Road hazard sign.
questions.answerB: Interstate route sign.
questions.answerC: School crossing sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are normally diamond-shaped and yellow, although orange warning signs are used in work areas. Such signs warn that you are approaching a hazardous location or an area where special rules apply.

questions.question: To enter a freeway:
questions.answerA: Signal, yield to existing traffic, and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving.
questions.answerB: Signal and enter the freeway. Freeway traffic must yield.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly so you can check traffic.
questions.answerD: Always come to a complete stop first.
questions.explanation: When merging into traffic, you should signal and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving. Always yield to other traffic when entering a roadway.

questions.question: If a crossing guard is directing traffic in a school zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the crossing guard.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the crossing guard's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the guard is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow rules that would be in place if no children were present.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, crossing guard, or law enforcement officer. Always drive with extra caution in a school zone.

questions.question: The fee for an instruction permit is:
questions.explanation: The minimum age to acquire an instruction permit is 15 years old. This permit allows a young person to learn to drive with the supervision of a licensed adult. The fee to obtain this permit is $3.50. Application test fees are not included.

questions.question: Who must yield when a driver is turning and a pedestrian is crossing without a traffic light?
questions.answerA: Whoever started moving last
questions.answerB: The driver
questions.answerC: Whoever is slower
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians when they are crossing at any intersection without a traffic light, whether or not there is a crosswalk.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: When meeting a car with blinding headlights, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your bright lights until the other vehicle dims theirs.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights on and off to warn the other driver.
questions.answerC: Dim your lights and then speed up to pass quickly.
questions.answerD: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle comes toward you with its high beams on, look away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the car has passed. This will keep you from being blinded.

questions.question: ____ greatly increase stopping distances and severity of crashes.
questions.answerA: High speeds
questions.answerB: Slow speeds
questions.answerC: Night drives
questions.explanation: High speeds greatly increase stopping distances and severity of crashes. The faster you drive, the greater the impact or striking power of your vehicle, should you be involved in a collision.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerA: The right lane.
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: You should honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling through an intersection.
questions.answerB: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.answerC: See a child who is about to run into the street.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used as a warning in situations where you think another driver or a pedestrian does not see you. For example, if a child begins to run into the street in front of your vehicle, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerA: A designated no passing zone
questions.answerB: A one-way traffic area
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: A single broken white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: The minimum age a person must be in order to obtain a motorcycle instruction permit is:
questions.answerA: 14 years old.
questions.answerB: 15 years old.
questions.answerC: 15 and one-half years old.
questions.explanation: You may apply for a motorcycle instruction permit to learn to operate a motorcycle. The minimum age you must be to be eligible to apply for a motorcycle instruction permit is 15 and one-half years old.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: That the road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: Fog can greatly reduce the visibility of other vehicles, pedestrians, and traffic signals. When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive cautiously and reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Not use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use low beam headlights to better illuminate the road and objects.
questions.explanation: Fog can greatly reduce your ability to see other vehicles, pedestrians, and traffic signals. When driving in fog, drive cautiously and at reduced speeds. Do not use high beam headlights. Low beams better illuminate the road and objects ahead in foggy conditions.

questions.question: When driving on major highways:
questions.answerA: Stay alert.
questions.answerB: Keep your eyes moving.
questions.answerC: Be ready to react to road hazards.
questions.explanation: It is important to stay alert on highways and be ready to react to unexpected hazards. To avoid "highway hypnosis," you should avoid looking at any one thing for more than a few seconds.

questions.question: If you fail the driving test three times:
questions.answerA: The examiner will give you a Driving Skills Examination Report.
questions.answerB: You must send your Examination Report to the Department of Revenue.
questions.answerC: The Department of Revenue will require driver training.
questions.explanation: If you fail the driving test three times, no further tests will be allowed without written authorization from the Department of Revenue. The examiner will give you a form that you must send to the department. After you send the form to the department, you will receive a letter from the department requiring additional behind-the-wheel driver training.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns of existing or possible hazards.
questions.answerB: Alerts drivers to school zones.
questions.answerC: Alerts drivers to public recreation areas.
questions.answerD: Alerts drivers to upcoming food and gas locations.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs warn drivers of existing or potential driving hazards. You will usually see these signs in yellow or orange.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Bicycle store.
questions.explanation: This sign (with the arrow below) indicates the location of a bicycle crossing/path. Drive with caution around this sign because bicycles likely regularly cross or ride beside traffic in the area.

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerB: The day after it rains.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: A leaking exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Cause excessive oil use.
questions.answerB: Require your vehicle to have a tune-up sooner than normal.
questions.answerC: Make you drowsy while driving.
questions.answerD: Set grass fires on country roads.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system helps remove toxic gases, reduce the noise, and cool the hot gases coming from a running engine. Fumes from a leaky exhaust system can cause death in a very short time. They can also make you drowsy while driving.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerA: Avoid sudden stops.
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: On the freeway, you see a "Merging traffic“ sign. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk at incoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Always remain at your present speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up to avoid congesting traffic.
questions.answerD: Move to another lane, if safe, to let traffic enter.
questions.explanation: When on a roadway with two or more lanes, you should make room for entering vehicles. If there is no one driving next to you, move over one lane.

questions.question: Which is the most common cause of traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: New drivers
questions.answerB: Human error
questions.answerC: Bad weather
questions.explanation: Crashes often occur when one driver does not see another vehicle or when a driver does something unexpected. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent traffic crashes.

questions.question: When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Accelerate as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Back up slowly.
questions.answerD: Not move until another driver waves you on.
questions.explanation: A green light tells you that you can go through the intersection. However, you must first yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: A license will be suspended if a driver:
questions.answerA: Refuses to submit to a chemical test.
questions.answerB: Drives 10 mph over the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Honks their horn in a residential area after midnight.
questions.answerD: Does not turn off their high beam lights around another vehicle.
questions.explanation: By operating a vehicle on Missouri roadways, a driver automatically consents to taking a chemical test to determine their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) when requested by an officer. If a driver refuses the test, their license will be suspended for one year.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal means that a ____ light will soon appear.
questions.answerA: Flashing yellow
questions.answerB: Steady green
questions.answerC: Steady red
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light on a traffic signal indicates that a steady red light will soon appear.

questions.question: If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly cut across traffic to make your turn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your blinker and make the turn from your current lane.
questions.answerC: Drive to the next intersection and make your turn then.
questions.answerD: Safely change lanes then put your vehicle in reverse to go back to the intersection.
questions.explanation: Never make last-minute turns. If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane to make the turn, drive to the next intersection and then make the turn from the proper lane.
